In the following sub-subsections we will try to discuss and investigate some issues (such as recommendations and techniques) which are useful to know and remember when tackling simple types of Diophantine exponential problems. The last sub-subsection of this subsection is dedicated to some general recommendations and guidelines about the use of the technique of modular reduction and analysis in solving Diophantine exponential equations (and equations involving exponentials) noting that modular reduction and analysis is the most common approach for tackling and solving Diophantine exponential equations (and equations involving exponentials) and hence it enjoys a special importance that requires special attention.

However, before we go through these details we would like to outline a general strategy for tackling and solving Diophantine exponential equations. In brief, the solutions of Diophantine exponential equations (and equations involving exponentials) are usually at the very low values of their variables (when solutions exist). Hence, the best strategy for solving these equations is to inspect these equations computationally (see §§\S§ 5) for solutions within a certain range of their variables that includes low values of their variables (e.g. between 0 and 15) and hence we have three main cases and scenarios (which determine our strategy and approach):
∙∙\bullet∙ No solution found: in this case we look for an argument (e.g. based on parity violation or modular contradiction) to prove that the given equation has no solution.
∙∙\bullet∙ A few solutions found (usually in the neighborhood of zero): in this case we look for an argument showing that there are no other solutions (i.e. at high values of their variables).
∙∙\bullet∙ Considerable number of solutions found: in this case we look for a pattern within the found solutions on which we can build an argument for the type of solutions (where such an argument should establish whether there are other solutions or not).

6.3.1 Magnitude Consideration

The very basic (and possibly trivial) Diophantine exponential equations can be solved by just inspecting the limitation on the magnitude of the two sides of the equation. For example, the following Diophantine exponential equations (where x,y∈ℕ0𝑥𝑦superscriptℕ0x,y\in\mathbb{N}^{0}italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT):
2x+3y=1superscript2𝑥superscript3𝑦12^{x}+3^{y}=12 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 4x+9y=2superscript4𝑥superscript9𝑦24^{x}+9^{y}=24 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 9 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2 5x+7y=40369232superscript5𝑥superscript7𝑦403692325^{x}+7^{y}=403692325 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 40369232
can be easily “solved” by noting that the first equation has no solution because the LHS cannot be less than 2, and the second equation has only the trivial solution x=y=0𝑥𝑦0x=y=0italic_x = italic_y = 0 because otherwise the LHS will be greater than 2, while the third equation (assuming it is solvable) must have solution(s) only for very low values of its variables and hence the solution(s) can be obtained computationally (knowing for sure, by this logical argument, that there is no other solution within the high values of its variables).[13] [13] [13] Actually, the third equation has only one solution which is x=6𝑥6x=6italic_x = 6 and y=9𝑦9y=9italic_y = 9.

6.3.2 Modular Reduction

The method of modular reduction is as common in solving exponential Diophantine equations as in solving polynomial Diophantine equations (see §§\S§ 6.2.4 and §§\S§ 7). As indicated earlier (and later), one of the common purposes of modular reduction is to simplify the equation (e.g. by removing some variables) or/and showing and revealing some “hidden” patterns and clues that can help in solving the Diophantine equation (noting that the employed modular reduction may not introduce any “visible” change on the original Diophantine equation apart from converting it from an ordinary equation to a congruence equation). The logical and mathematical foundations for the use of modular reduction in solving Diophantine equations will be outlined later on (see §§\S§ 7.1) and hence the unfamiliar reader should refer to that subsection.

For example, we can easily solve the following exponential Diophantine equation (i.e. find out that it has no solution in ℕ0superscriptℕ0\mathbb{N}^{0}blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT):

4x−12y=a(a=1⁢ or ⁢a=6⁢ or ⁢a=7)superscript4𝑥superscript12𝑦𝑎𝑎1 or 𝑎6 or 𝑎74^{x}-12^{y}=a\hskip 56.9055pt(a=1\textrm{ or }a=6\textrm{ or }a=7)4 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 12 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_a ( italic_a = 1 or italic_a = 6 or italic_a = 7 ) (3)

by reducing it in modulo 13 to get: 4x−12y=13asuperscript13superscript4𝑥superscript12𝑦𝑎4^{x}-12^{y}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle 13}}{{=}}a4 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 12 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG 13 end_ARG end_RELOP italic_a which has no solution for a=1,6,7𝑎167a=1,6,7italic_a = 1 , 6 , 7 (since 1,6,71671,6,71 , 6 , 7 are not modular values of 4x−12ysuperscript4𝑥superscript12𝑦4^{x}-12^{y}4 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 12 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for any combination of x,y∈ℕ0𝑥𝑦superscriptℕ0x,y\in\mathbb{N}^{0}italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) and hence we can easily conclude that the original Diophantine equation has no solution (see §§\S§ 7.1).

Similarly, the exponential Diophantine equation:

4x−3y=1(x,y∈ℕ0)superscript4𝑥superscript3𝑦1𝑥𝑦superscriptℕ04^{x}-3^{y}=1\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{N}^{0})4 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

can be solved by noting that for x>1𝑥1x>1italic_x > 1 we have:

4x−3y=22⁢x−3y=(23×22⁢x−3)−3y=(8×22⁢x−3)−3y=8−3y≠81superscript4𝑥superscript3𝑦superscript22𝑥superscript3𝑦superscript23superscript22𝑥3superscript3𝑦8superscript22𝑥3superscript3𝑦superscript8superscript3𝑦superscript814^{x}-3^{y}=2^{2x}-3^{y}=(2^{3}\times 2^{2x-3})-3^{y}=(8\times 2^{2x-3})-3^{y}% \stackrel{{\scriptstyle 8}}{{=}}-3^{y}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle 8}}{{\neq}}14 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_x - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( 8 × 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_x - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG end_RELOP - 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG ≠ end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG end_RELOP 1

and hence it has no solution. So, if it has any solution then x𝑥xitalic_x must be 0 or 1. A simple inspection will then reveal that the only possible solution of this Diophantine equation is (x,y)=(1,1)𝑥𝑦11(x,y)=(1,1)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( 1 , 1 ). The same method and argument apply to the exponential Diophantine equation:

4x−3y=3(x,y∈ℕ0)superscript4𝑥superscript3𝑦3𝑥𝑦superscriptℕ04^{x}-3^{y}=3\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{N}^{0})4 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 3 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

where we can prove that the only possible solution of this equation is (x,y)=(1,0)𝑥𝑦10(x,y)=(1,0)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( 1 , 0 ).

There are many other examples (some of which will be given later) for the use of modular reduction as a tool for solving exponential Diophantine equations.

It is important to note that in many cases modular analysis may require using more than one modulo for reduction and analysis. For example, the equation:

5x−3y=2superscript5𝑥superscript3𝑦25^{x}-3^{y}=25 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2 (4)

can be solved by reducing it in modulo 9 where the solution (x,y)=(1,1)𝑥𝑦11(x,y)=(1,1)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( 1 , 1 ) is found for the case of 3y=93superscript9superscript3𝑦33^{y}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle 9}}{{=}}33 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG end_RELOP 3 (i.e. 5x−31=2superscript5𝑥superscript3125^{x}-3^{1}=25 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2). Further analysis in modulo 28 is then applied to show that there is no solution in the other case (i.e. 3y=90superscript9superscript3𝑦03^{y}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle 9}}{{=}}03 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG end_RELOP 0 or x=65superscript6𝑥5x\stackrel{{\scriptstyle 6}}{{=}}5italic_x start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG end_RELOP 5).

Another example is the equation:

3x+5y=z2superscript3𝑥superscript5𝑦superscript𝑧23^{x}+5^{y}=z^{2}3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (5)

where its analysis in modulo 3 and modulo 9 leads to obtaining its two solutions, i.e. (x,y,z)=(1,0,±2)𝑥𝑦𝑧10plus-or-minus2(x,y,z)=(1,0,\pm 2)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ( 1 , 0 , ± 2 ).

Also see the examples of §§\S§ 6.3.3.

6.3.3 Parity and Modular Analysis

In many cases, Diophantine exponential equations can be solved by a combination of parity and modular analysis (noting that parity analysis is a form of modular analysis; see §§\S§ 2.5). For example, the equation:

2x−3y=1superscript2𝑥superscript3𝑦12^{x}-3^{y}=12 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1

can be solved by considering the parity of x𝑥xitalic_x where the equation is reduced in modulo 3 for odd x𝑥xitalic_x to get the solution (x,y)=(1,0)𝑥𝑦10(x,y)=(1,0)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( 1 , 0 ), and analyzed in modulo 8 for even x𝑥xitalic_x to get the solution (x,y)=(2,1)𝑥𝑦21(x,y)=(2,1)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( 2 , 1 ).

A similar method applies to the equation:

3x−2y=1superscript3𝑥superscript2𝑦13^{x}-2^{y}=13 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1

by considering the parity of x𝑥xitalic_x where the equation is reduced in modulo 8 for odd x𝑥xitalic_x to get the solution (x,y)=(1,1)𝑥𝑦11(x,y)=(1,1)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( 1 , 1 ). The equation is then analyzed further for even x𝑥xitalic_x where it is factorized as (3k−1)⁢(3k+1)=2ysuperscript3𝑘1superscript3𝑘1superscript2𝑦(3^{k}-1)(3^{k}+1)=2^{y}( 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 ) ( 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 ) = 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and analyzed to infer the power of 2 to which these factors correspond and this analysis leads to the only solution in this case which is (x,y)=(2,3)𝑥𝑦23(x,y)=(2,3)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( 2 , 3 ).

6.3.4 Recommendations about Modular Analysis

We would like to draw the attention in this sub-subsection to the following recommendations and guidelines which we can gather from our personal experience (as well as from the literature) about the use of the technique of modular reduction in solving exponential Diophantine equations:[14] [14] [14] In fact, most of these recommendations and guidelines also apply to other types of Diophantine equations.

  1. 1.

    Try to find and use a reduction modulo that is as small as possible so that you deal with small or modest residue system that is easy to manage and deal with. A systematic inspection to candidate reduction moduli in their increasing magnitude should lead to the identification of the smallest modulo that is appropriate for that purpose (if it exists).

  2. 2.

    Try to choose (when you have a choice) a reduction modulo k𝑘kitalic_k so that the base of interest n𝑛nitalic_n for that reduction modulo has a low integer order, i.e. Ok⁢nsubscript𝑂𝑘𝑛O_{k}nitalic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n.[15] [15] [15] We note that “the base of interest” is more general than dealing with only one powered base (i.e. when modular reduction eliminates the powers of other bases) and dealing with more than one powered base (i.e. when more than one powered base remain after modular reduction). For instance, if the base of interest is 7 (e.g. we are dealing with 7xsuperscript7𝑥7^{x}7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) then O10⁢7=4subscript𝑂1074O_{10}7=4italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 7 = 4 while O13⁢7=12subscript𝑂13712O_{13}7=12italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 13 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 7 = 12 and hence if we have a choice then 10 is a better reduction modulo. The reason for this is that low integer order means fewer cases to deal with and easier investigation and management.

  3. 3.

    Try to choose (when you have a choice) a reduction modulo that is prime (not composite) or at least a power of prime. This should reduce the complications due to the obvious advantages of dealing with prime moduli (although this can be in conflict with the previous recommendation).

  4. 4.

    Consider using more than one reduction modulo (i.e. in more than one modular reduction operation) associated with comparison and analysis of the results of the different reduction moduli. Such comparison and analysis can lead to producing a logical/mathematical argument that leads to the solution of the problem in hand. Some examples for using more than one modulo were given earlier (see for instance the analysis of Eqs. 4 and 5).

  5. 5.

    There is no guarantee that the problem in hand can be tackled by modular reduction in an appropriate way (commensurate with the nature and size of the problem) and hence be prepared for possible failure. Accordingly, be prepared to give up after reasonable time and effort (i.e. don’t be bogged down!).[16] [16] [16] This recommendation (in our view) is especially important when dealing with exponential equations because the search for an appropriate reduction modulo in this case is usually demanding and time consuming and hence it can waste considerable amount of time if we keep trying and trying.

6.4 Mixed Polynomial-Exponential Equations

There is no single standard method or technique for solving this type of Diophantine equations. However, the methods and techniques used for solving polynomial and exponential equations (see §§\S§ 6.1, 6.2 and 6.3) are generally used to solve this type of Diophantine equations (since the equation is a mix of these types of Diophantine equations). It is important to note in this context the special importance of using modular reduction which is seemingly the most common technique in tackling this type of problems (although it is usually associated with other techniques and tricks and further modular and non-modular analysis). This should be understandable noting the ability of modular reduction to eliminate one type of the mix (i.e. the polynomial type and the exponential type) if such elimination is required as well as its exceptional ability to simplify the equation in general (with and without elimination of one type) and expose it to the versatile (and relatively simple) tools and rules of modular arithmetic. We should also mention in this regard that the use of modular reduction is common in tackling both polynomial and exponential types of Diophantine equations (see §§\S§ 6.2.4 and 6.3.2) and hence it should also be common in tackling mixed polynomial-exponential Diophantine equations.

In the following sub-subsections we will present a sample of this type of Diophantine equations and the methods used in their solutions. This should give an idea about the methods used in solving this type of equations.

6.4.1 Simple Inspection

Some mixed polynomial-exponential Diophantine equations are so trivial that they can be “solved” by just simple inspection. For example, if we write the equation:

7x−8y−z=0(x,y∈ℕ0,z∈ℤ)7^{x}-8^{y}-z=0\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{N}^{0},\ z\in\mathbb{Z})7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 8 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_z = 0 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z ∈ blackboard_Z )

as z=7x−8y𝑧superscript7𝑥superscript8𝑦z=7^{x}-8^{y}italic_z = 7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 8 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT then it is obvious that there is no restriction on z𝑧zitalic_z (other than being integer) and hence we are free to assign any value (within the domain) to its two exponential variables which they fix (as soon as they are assigned) the value of z𝑧zitalic_z. So, the solutions of this equation are obviously (x,y,z)=(k,s,7k−8s)𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑘𝑠superscript7𝑘superscript8𝑠(x,y,z)=(k,s,7^{k}-8^{s})( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ( italic_k , italic_s , 7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 8 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) where k,s∈ℕ0𝑘𝑠superscriptℕ0k,s\in\mathbb{N}^{0}italic_k , italic_s ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

6.4.6 Modular Reduction with Parity Analysis

For example, the equation:

6.4.7 Classification with Parity Analysis

For example, the equation:

7x−8y−2z=0(x,y∈ℕ0,z∈ℤ)7^{x}-8^{y}-2z=0\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{N}^{0},\ z\in\mathbb{Z})7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 8 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_z = 0 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z ∈ blackboard_Z )

can be solved by classifying it according to the value of its exponential variables associated with parity analysis. More specifically, the case x=0𝑥0x=0italic_x = 0 and y>0𝑦0y>0italic_y > 0 as well as the case x>0𝑥0x>0italic_x > 0 and y>0𝑦0y>0italic_y > 0 have no solution due to parity violation. So, all we need to consider is the case x=y=0𝑥𝑦0x=y=0italic_x = italic_y = 0 which leads to the trivial solution (x,y,z)=(0,0,0)𝑥𝑦𝑧000(x,y,z)=(0,0,0)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ( 0 , 0 , 0 ) and the case x>0𝑥0x>0italic_x > 0 and y=0𝑦0y=0italic_y = 0 which leads to the obvious solution (x,y,z)=(k,0,7k−12)𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑘0superscript7𝑘12(x,y,z)=\left(k,0,\frac{7^{k}-1}{2}\right)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ( italic_k , 0 , divide start_ARG 7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) where k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}italic_k ∈ blackboard_N.

6.5 Equations Involving Roots

Equations involving roots may not be classified technically as Diophantine equations although this will not prevent us from including them in our investigation due to the obvious merit and justification of this inclusion and their undeniable qualification to be treated as such. There are a variety of methods (or techniques or tricks or ……\ldots…) for tackling Diophantine equations involving roots. In the following sub-subsections we present some of the most common of these methods with illuminating and illustrating examples.

6.5.1 Simple Inspection

Some of the Diophantine equations involving roots are so trivial that they can be “solved” by just simple inspection. For example, the equation:

6.5.2 Enumeration

6.6 Equations Involving Fractions

Again, equations involving fractions may not be classified technically as Diophantine equations although this will not affect our decision to include them in our investigation (justified at least by practical considerations even if they are not Diophantine equations from a theoretical viewpoint due to the limitation of the definition of Diophantine equations). Anyway, there are various methods and techniques for tackling Diophantine equations involving fractions (depending for instance on their types and number of variables). In the following sub-subsections we will outline some of the most common of these methods presented and demonstrated within illuminating examples.

6.6.1 Magnitude Analysis

For example, the equations:

1x+1y+1z=4and1x+1y+1z=3(x,y,z∈ℤ,xyz≠0)\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}=4\hskip 56.9055pt\textrm{and}\hskip 56.905% 5pt\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}=3\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y,z\in\mathbb{Z},\ % xyz\neq 0)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_z end_ARG = 4 and divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_z end_ARG = 3 ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y italic_z ≠ 0 )

can be easily solved by magnitude analysis where the first equation has no solution because its LHS cannot be greater than 3 (i.e. when x=y=z=1𝑥𝑦𝑧1x=y=z=1italic_x = italic_y = italic_z = 1), while the second equation has only one solution (i.e. x=y=z=1𝑥𝑦𝑧1x=y=z=1italic_x = italic_y = italic_z = 1) because if any one of the variables is not equal to 1 then the LHS will be less than 3.

6.6.2 Sign and Magnitude Analysis

For example, the equation:

xy+yx=1(x,y∈ℤ,xy≠0)\frac{x}{y}+\frac{y}{x}=1\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ xy\neq 0)divide start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG = 1 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y ≠ 0 )

can be solved by noting that if this equation has a solution then x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y must have the same sign (because otherwise the sum will be negative) and hence (whether x≥y𝑥𝑦x\geq yitalic_x ≥ italic_y or x<y𝑥𝑦x<yitalic_x < italic_y) the LHS must be greater than 1, i.e. the equation has no solution.

Many similar equations can be analyzed and solved by this method, e.g. the equation:

xy+xy=1(x,y∈ℤ,y≠0)\frac{x}{y}+xy=1\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ y\neq 0)divide start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG + italic_x italic_y = 1 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_y ≠ 0 )

has no solution because x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y must have the same sign (otherwise the sum will be negative) and hence (whether x≥y𝑥𝑦x\geq yitalic_x ≥ italic_y or x<y𝑥𝑦x<yitalic_x < italic_y) the LHS must be greater than 1 (noting that x=0𝑥0x=0italic_x = 0 is not a possibility).

This also applies to the equations:

1x+1y=231x+2y=34(x,y∈ℤ,xy≠0)\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}=\frac{2}{3}\hskip 56.9055pt\frac{1}{x}+\frac{2}{y}=% \frac{3}{4}\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ xy\neq 0)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG = divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y ≠ 0 )

which can be solved by this method (where the details can be found in [3]).

6.6.3 Divisibility Analysis

Some equations can be manipulated in one (or more) form that facilitates simple divisibility analysis which leads to the solutions. For example, the equation:

1x+1y=z(x,y,z∈ℤ,xy≠0)\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}=z\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y,z\in\mathbb{Z},\ xy\neq 0)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG = italic_z ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y ≠ 0 )

can be manipulated into the following two forms:

1+xy=x⁢zyx+1=y⁢zformulae-sequence1𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑧𝑦𝑥1𝑦𝑧1+\frac{x}{y}=xz\hskip 85.35826pt\frac{y}{x}+1=yz1 + divide start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG = italic_x italic_z divide start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + 1 = italic_y italic_z

which imply y=±x𝑦plus-or-minus𝑥y=\pm xitalic_y = ± italic_x and this (with extra basic analysis) will lead to the required solutions.

6.6.4 Separation of Variables with Divisibility Analysis

For example, the equation:

14x+y19=25(x,y∈ℤ,x≠0)\frac{14}{x}+\frac{y}{19}=25\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ x\neq 0)divide start_ARG 14 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_ARG 19 end_ARG = 25 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x ≠ 0 ) (8)

can be manipulated to become:

y=475−266x𝑦475266𝑥y=475-\frac{266}{x}italic_y = 475 - divide start_ARG 266 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG

Now, by a basic divisibility analysis (i.e. x𝑥xitalic_x must be a divisor of 266) we can easily obtain all the (sixteen) solutions of the original Diophantine equation.

This method also applies to the equation:

20x+33y=2(x,y∈ℤ,xy≠0)\frac{20}{x}+\frac{33}{y}=2\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ xy\neq 0)divide start_ARG 20 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG 33 end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG = 2 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y ≠ 0 ) (9)

which can be manipulated to become:

x=20⁢y2⁢y−33𝑥20𝑦2𝑦33x=\frac{20y}{2y-33}italic_x = divide start_ARG 20 italic_y end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_y - 33 end_ARG

where by a simple divisibility analysis (i.e. 2⁢y−332𝑦332y-332 italic_y - 33 must be a divisor of 330) we can obtain all the (fifteen) solutions of the given Diophantine equation.

Another example of this approach is the equation:

x8+y5−3z=7(x,y,z∈ℤ,z≠0)\frac{x}{8}+\frac{y}{5}-\frac{3}{z}=7\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y,z\in\mathbb{Z},\ z% \neq 0)divide start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_ARG 5 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG italic_z end_ARG = 7 ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_z ≠ 0 )

which can be reduced to the form:

z=1205⁢x+8⁢y−280𝑧1205𝑥8𝑦280z=\frac{120}{5x+8y-280}italic_z = divide start_ARG 120 end_ARG start_ARG 5 italic_x + 8 italic_y - 280 end_ARG

and hence it is solved by divisibility analysis.

6.6.5 Conversion to Polynomial Equation

Some Diophantine equations involving fractions can be converted to polynomial equations by multiplying the entire equation by a suitable factor (and hence it is solved as a polynomial Diophantine equation; see §§\S§ 6.1 and §§\S§ 6.2). For example, the equation:

xy+yx=2(x,y∈ℤ,xy≠0)\frac{x}{y}+\frac{y}{x}=2\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ xy\neq 0)divide start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG = 2 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y ≠ 0 ) (10)

can be solved by multiplying the equation by x⁢y𝑥𝑦xyitalic_x italic_y and rearranging to get x2+y2−2⁢x⁢y=0superscript𝑥2superscript𝑦22𝑥𝑦0x^{2}+y^{2}-2xy=0italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_x italic_y = 0, i.e. (x−y)2=0superscript𝑥𝑦20(x-y)^{2}=0( italic_x - italic_y ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0. Hence, we conclude that the general solution of the given equation is (x,y)=(k,k)𝑥𝑦𝑘𝑘(x,y)=(k,k)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( italic_k , italic_k ) where k∈ℤ𝑘ℤk\in\mathbb{Z}italic_k ∈ blackboard_Z and k≠0𝑘0k\neq 0italic_k ≠ 0.

In fact, this method applies to the more general version of Eq. 10, i.e.

xy+yx=z(x,y,z∈ℤ,xy≠0)\frac{x}{y}+\frac{y}{x}=z\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y,z\in\mathbb{Z},\ xy\neq 0)divide start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG = italic_z ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y ≠ 0 )

to prove that this equation has no solution except for z=±2𝑧plus-or-minus2z=\pm 2italic_z = ± 2. This is achieved by forming the discriminant of the equation x2−z⁢x⁢y+y2=0superscript𝑥2𝑧𝑥𝑦superscript𝑦20x^{2}-zxy+y^{2}=0italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_z italic_x italic_y + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 (treated as a quadratic in x𝑥xitalic_x or as a quadratic in y𝑦yitalic_y; see §§\S§ 6.2.6) where a detailed analysis of the discriminant will lead to the required conclusion (i.e. there is no solution except for z=±2𝑧plus-or-minus2z=\pm 2italic_z = ± 2) as well as finding the solutions when z=±2𝑧plus-or-minus2z=\pm 2italic_z = ± 2.

Another example is the equation:

xy−yx=1(x,y∈ℤ,xy≠0)\frac{x}{y}-\frac{y}{x}=1\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ xy\neq 0)divide start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG = 1 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y ≠ 0 ) (11)

which can be solved by multiplying it by x⁢y𝑥𝑦xyitalic_x italic_y and rearranging to get x2−x⁢y−y2=0superscript𝑥2𝑥𝑦superscript𝑦20x^{2}-xy-y^{2}=0italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_x italic_y - italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0. On treating this as a one-variable quadratic equation in x𝑥xitalic_x (see §§\S§ 6.2.6) and analyzing its discriminant we conclude that the given equation has no solution.

A similar method applies to the equation:

xy−yx=2(x,y∈ℤ,xy≠0)\frac{x}{y}-\frac{y}{x}=2\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ xy\neq 0)divide start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG = 2 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y ≠ 0 )

which can be solved by multiplying it by x⁢y𝑥𝑦xyitalic_x italic_y and rearranging to get x2=2⁢x⁢y+y2superscript𝑥22𝑥𝑦superscript𝑦2x^{2}=2xy+y^{2}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2 italic_x italic_y + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and hence:

2⁢x2=x2+x2=x2+(2⁢x⁢y+y2)=x2+2⁢x⁢y+y2=(x+y)22superscript𝑥2superscript𝑥2superscript𝑥2superscript𝑥22𝑥𝑦superscript𝑦2superscript𝑥22𝑥𝑦superscript𝑦2superscript𝑥𝑦22x^{2}=x^{2}+x^{2}=x^{2}+(2xy+y^{2})=x^{2}+2xy+y^{2}=(x+y)^{2}2 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( 2 italic_x italic_y + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 italic_x italic_y + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_x + italic_y ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

On taking the square root of both sides we get: x⁢2=±(x+y)𝑥2plus-or-minus𝑥𝑦x\sqrt{2}=\pm(x+y)italic_x square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG = ± ( italic_x + italic_y ) which is impossible because x⁢2𝑥2x\sqrt{2}italic_x square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG is irrational while (x+y)𝑥𝑦(x+y)( italic_x + italic_y ) is an integer. So, we conclude that the given equation has no solution.

In fact, the method of Eq. 11 applies to the more general version of Eq. 11, i.e.

xy−yx=z(x,y,z∈ℤ,xy≠0)\frac{x}{y}-\frac{y}{x}=z\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y,z\in\mathbb{Z},\ xy\neq 0)divide start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG = italic_z ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y ≠ 0 )

to prove that this equation has no solution except for z=0𝑧0z=0italic_z = 0 where this is achieved by analyzing the discriminant of the equation y2+z⁢x⁢y−x2=0superscript𝑦2𝑧𝑥𝑦superscript𝑥20y^{2}+zxy-x^{2}=0italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_z italic_x italic_y - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 (which is obtained by multiplying the given equation by x⁢y𝑥𝑦xyitalic_x italic_y) as a quadratic in y𝑦yitalic_y (see §§\S§ 6.2.6). The analysis will lead to the required conclusion as well as finding the solutions when z=0𝑧0z=0italic_z = 0.

Conversion to polynomial equation can also be used to solve the equation:

1x+1y=1(x,y∈ℤ,xy≠0)\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}=1\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ xy\neq 0)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG = 1 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y ≠ 0 )

where it is reduced to the form (1−x)⁢(1−y)=1=(−1)⁢(−1)1𝑥1𝑦111(1-x)(1-y)=1=(-1)(-1)( 1 - italic_x ) ( 1 - italic_y ) = 1 = ( - 1 ) ( - 1 ) and hence its only solution (i.e. x=y=2𝑥𝑦2x=y=2italic_x = italic_y = 2) can be obtained by factorization analysis (as indicated).

6.6.6 Comparison to a Similar Equation

Some equations can be easily solved by comparing them to similar equations whose solutions are known (or can be obtained easily). For example, the equation:

14x−y19=25(x,y∈ℤ,x≠0)\frac{14}{x}-\frac{y}{19}=25\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ x\neq 0)divide start_ARG 14 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_ARG 19 end_ARG = 25 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x ≠ 0 )

can be easily solved by comparing it to Eq. 8 where we write our equation as 14x+Y19=2514𝑥𝑌1925\frac{14}{x}+\frac{Y}{19}=25divide start_ARG 14 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_ARG 19 end_ARG = 25 (with Y=−y𝑌𝑦Y=-yitalic_Y = - italic_y) and hence we should have the same solutions for (x,Y𝑥𝑌x,Yitalic_x , italic_Y) as those found for Eq. 8. The final solutions for our equation are then obtained by reversing the sign of Y𝑌Yitalic_Y.

This method of comparison similarly applies to the equation:

20x−33y=2(x,y∈ℤ,xy≠0)\frac{20}{x}-\frac{33}{y}=2\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ xy\neq 0)divide start_ARG 20 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG - divide start_ARG 33 end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG = 2 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y ≠ 0 ) (12)

which can be compared to Eq. 9 and hence its solutions are obtained from the solutions of Eq. 9 by reversing the sign of y𝑦yitalic_y. This is because if we write Eq. 12 as 20x+33−y=220𝑥33𝑦2\frac{20}{x}+\frac{33}{-y}=2divide start_ARG 20 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG 33 end_ARG start_ARG - italic_y end_ARG = 2 then it is no more than Eq. 9 with the sign of y𝑦yitalic_y being reversed.

6.6.7 Symmetry-Based Ordering and Magnitude Analysis

Some equations have a symmetry in their variables that can be exploited in an analysis based on ordering the magnitude of the variables. For example, the equations:

1x+1y+1z=1and1x+1y+1z=2(x,y,z∈ℕ)formulae-sequence1𝑥1𝑦1𝑧1and1𝑥1𝑦1𝑧2𝑥𝑦𝑧ℕ\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}=1\hskip 56.9055pt\textrm{and}\hskip 56.905% 5pt\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}=2\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y,z\in\mathbb{N})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_z end_ARG = 1 and divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_z end_ARG = 2 ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ blackboard_N )

can be investigated preliminarily under the ordering assumption that x≤y≤z𝑥𝑦𝑧x\leq y\leq zitalic_x ≤ italic_y ≤ italic_z and hence their solutions (under this assumption) are obtained rather easily by exploiting the restrictions on the magnitude of the variables where these restrictions are based on the restriction on the magnitude of the LHS of these equations (which is imposed by their RHS) as well as the restriction imposed by the ordering assumption. The remaining solutions are then obtained by lifting the ordering assumption and hence permuting the variables in the initial solutions (i.e. the solutions obtained under the ordering assumption) where permuting the variables in the initial solutions is justified by the aforementioned symmetry. Hence, all the solutions are obtained in this two-stage process that exploits and employs symmetry, ordering and magnitude restrictions.

Also see §§\S§ 10.

6.7 Equations Involving Roots and Fractions

The best approach for tackling this sort of equations is to linearize the radicals (i.e. the roots are replaced by non-radical symbols such as replacing x𝑥\sqrt{x}square-root start_ARG italic_x end_ARG by X𝑋Xitalic_X) and hence the problem is reduced in difficulty because we deal first with an equation that involves non-radical fractions while dealing with the issue of radicals is deferred to the end (where it is usually managed rather easily by raising the variables of the obtained solutions to suitable powers). For example, the equation:

1x+1y+1z=2(x,y,z∈ℕ)1𝑥1𝑦1𝑧2𝑥𝑦𝑧ℕ\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{y}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{z}}=2\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y% ,z\in\mathbb{N})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_x end_ARG end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_y end_ARG end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_z end_ARG end_ARG = 2 ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ blackboard_N ) (13)

can be solved by converting it first to the form:

1X+1Y+1Z=2(X,Y,Z∈ℕ)1𝑋1𝑌1𝑍2𝑋𝑌𝑍ℕ\frac{1}{X}+\frac{1}{Y}+\frac{1}{Z}=2\hskip 56.9055pt(X,Y,Z\in\mathbb{N})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_X end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG = 2 ( italic_X , italic_Y , italic_Z ∈ blackboard_N ) (14)

where the latter equation is solved as an equation involving fractions (see §§\S§ 6.6). The final solutions (i.e. the solutions of Eq. 13) are then obtained by squaring the values of the variables of the solutions of Eq. 14. Many other similar equations can be dealt with by the same method.

6.8 Equations involving Factorials

A common approach in this type of problems is to obtain the solutions for the low values of factorial by inspection while the cases of high values of factorial are analyzed and tackled by a more general approach (e.g. by modular reduction). However, other (more versatile) tricks and techniques may be required or employed to solve this type of problems (e.g. when the factorial term is scaled by an integer factor). Some of these issues and details are demonstrated and clarified in the following examples:

  1. 1.

    The equation:

    11⁢x−y!=13(x∈ℤ,y∈ℕ0)11𝑥𝑦13formulae-sequence𝑥ℤ𝑦superscriptℕ011x-y!=13\hskip 56.9055pt(x\in\mathbb{Z},\ y\in\mathbb{N}^{0})11 italic_x - italic_y ! = 13 ( italic_x ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

    has no solution for y<13𝑦13y<13italic_y < 13 (where this result is obtained by inspection). For y≥13𝑦13y\geq 13italic_y ≥ 13 we have 11⁢x=130superscript1311𝑥011x\stackrel{{\scriptstyle 13}}{{=}}011 italic_x start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG 13 end_ARG end_RELOP 0 whose solution is x=13⁢k𝑥13𝑘x=13kitalic_x = 13 italic_k where k∈ℤ𝑘ℤk\in\mathbb{Z}italic_k ∈ blackboard_Z. On substituting this in the given equation and simplifying we get k=(y!/13)+111𝑘𝑦13111k=\frac{(y!/13)+1}{11}italic_k = divide start_ARG ( italic_y ! / 13 ) + 1 end_ARG start_ARG 11 end_ARG which implies that k𝑘kitalic_k cannot be an integer and hence the given equation has no solution.

  2. 2.

    The equation:

    x2−y!=3(x∈ℤ,y∈ℕ0)superscript𝑥2𝑦3formulae-sequence𝑥ℤ𝑦superscriptℕ0x^{2}-y!=3\hskip 56.9055pt(x\in\mathbb{Z},\ y\in\mathbb{N}^{0})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_y ! = 3 ( italic_x ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

    has no solution for y>3𝑦3y>3italic_y > 3 because x2=43superscript4superscript𝑥23x^{2}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle 4}}{{=}}3italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG end_RELOP 3 (which we obtain by reducing the given Diophantine equation in modulo 4) has no solution (since 3 is not a quadratic residue of 4). Hence, if there is any solution then we must have y=0,1,2,3𝑦0123y=0,1,2,3italic_y = 0 , 1 , 2 , 3. So, by inspecting these values of y𝑦yitalic_y we get all the solutions of the given equation, i.e. (x,y)=(±2,0)𝑥𝑦plus-or-minus20(x,y)=(\pm 2,0)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( ± 2 , 0 ), (±2,1)plus-or-minus21(\pm 2,1)( ± 2 , 1 ), (±3,3)plus-or-minus33(\pm 3,3)( ± 3 , 3 ).
    The equation:

    x2−y!=2(x∈ℤ,y∈ℕ0)superscript𝑥2𝑦2formulae-sequence𝑥ℤ𝑦superscriptℕ0x^{2}-y!=2\hskip 56.9055pt(x\in\mathbb{Z},\ y\in\mathbb{N}^{0})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_y ! = 2 ( italic_x ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

    can be similarly analyzed and solved (where reduction in modulo 3 is used for y>2𝑦2y>2italic_y > 2 with inspection of y=0,1,2𝑦012y=0,1,2italic_y = 0 , 1 , 2).

  3. 3.

    The equation:

    16⁢x+9⁢y!=121(x∈ℤ,y∈ℕ0)16𝑥9𝑦121formulae-sequence𝑥ℤ𝑦superscriptℕ016x+9y!=121\hskip 56.9055pt(x\in\mathbb{Z},\ y\in\mathbb{N}^{0})16 italic_x + 9 italic_y ! = 121 ( italic_x ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

    has no solution for y>1𝑦1y>1italic_y > 1 (due to parity violation) and hence it is solvable only for y=0,1𝑦01y=0,1italic_y = 0 , 1 (i.e. x=7𝑥7x=7italic_x = 7 corresponding to y=0,1𝑦01y=0,1italic_y = 0 , 1).

  4. 4.

    The equation:

    x2+y2−z!=3(x,y∈ℤ,z∈ℕ0)x^{2}+y^{2}-z!=3\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ z\in\mathbb{N}^{0})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_z ! = 3 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_z ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

    can be solved by noting that for z>3𝑧3z>3italic_z > 3 we have x2+y2=43superscript4superscript𝑥2superscript𝑦23x^{2}+y^{2}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle 4}}{{=}}3italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG end_RELOP 3 which has no solution and hence all we need to do is to inspect z=0,1,2,3𝑧0123z=0,1,2,3italic_z = 0 , 1 , 2 , 3 which lead to its (twenty) solutions.

  5. 5.

    The equation:

    x2+y2+z!=24(x,y∈ℤ,z∈ℕ0)x^{2}+y^{2}+z!=24\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ z\in\mathbb{N}^{0})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_z ! = 24 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_z ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

    The equation:

    3x+5y+15z!=17(x,y∈ℤ,z∈ℕ0)3x+5y+15z!=17\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ z\in\mathbb{N}^{0})3 italic_x + 5 italic_y + 15 italic_z ! = 17 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_z ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

  7. 7.

    The equation:

    2x+3y−6z!=222(x,y∈ℤ,z∈ℕ0)2x+3y-6z!=222\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ z\in\mathbb{N}^{0})2 italic_x + 3 italic_y - 6 italic_z ! = 222 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_z ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

6.9 Trigonometric Equations

The simple (and most common types) of trigonometric Diophantine equations can be solved rather easily by investigating the cyclic behavior of the terms of the equation and considering all the combinations (of the values of these terms) that satisfy the given equation. The following examples should give a reasonable insight about how to tackle and solve (the common types) of trigonometric Diophantine equations:

  1. 1.

    The equation:

    3⁢sin⁡(x⁢π2)−4⁢sin⁡(y⁢π2)=1(x,y∈ℤ)3𝑥𝜋24𝑦𝜋21𝑥𝑦ℤ3\sin\left(\frac{x\pi}{2}\right)-4\sin\left(\frac{y\pi}{2}\right)=1\hskip 56.9% 055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z})3 roman_sin ( divide start_ARG italic_x italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) - 4 roman_sin ( divide start_ARG italic_y italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) = 1 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z )

  2. 2.

    The equation:

    5⁢sin⁡(x⁢π2)+cos⁡(y⁢π)=3(x,y∈ℤ)5𝑥𝜋2𝑦𝜋3𝑥𝑦ℤ5\sin\left(\frac{x\pi}{2}\right)+\cos(y\pi)=3\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z})5 roman_sin ( divide start_ARG italic_x italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) + roman_cos ( italic_y italic_π ) = 3 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z )

Therefore, the term 5⁢sin⁡(x⁢π2)5𝑥𝜋25\sin\left(\frac{x\pi}{2}\right)5 roman_sin ( divide start_ARG italic_x italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) takes the values 0,5,−50550,5,-50 , 5 , - 5 while the term cos⁡(y⁢π)𝑦𝜋\cos(y\pi)roman_cos ( italic_y italic_π ) takes the values 1,−1111,-11 , - 1. 7 Reduction and Analysis by Modular Arithmetic

Reduction and analysis by modular arithmetic is very common method for solving various types of Diophantine equations, and hence considering modular arithmetic as an aiding technique for solving Diophantine equations is highly recommended especially when dealing with polynomial and exponential Diophantine equations. In fact, we already discussed this method within the context of its use in solving various types of Diophantine equations (see for instance §§\S§ 6.2.4 and §§\S§ 6.3.2). So, in this section we discuss some general issues about this method (namely its logical and mathematical foundations, its purposes and some recommendations and guidelines about its use and employment highlighting finally its importance for non-solvability).

7.1 Logical and Mathematical Foundations

Regarding the logical and mathematical foundations of the use of modular arithmetic in solving Diophantine equations, we refer the reader to §§\S§ §§\S§ 2.7.6 of [2] (also see §§\S§ 8.1 of [3]) where we discussed this subject[18] [18] [18] We mean the subject of relationship between the ordinary (Diophantine) equation and the corresponding congruence equation, e.g. the relationship between the Diophantine equation x2+3⁢x⁢y=0superscript𝑥23𝑥𝑦0x^{2}+3xy=0italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 3 italic_x italic_y = 0 and the congruence equation x2+3⁢x⁢y=30superscript3superscript𝑥23𝑥𝑦0x^{2}+3xy\stackrel{{\scriptstyle 3}}{{=}}0italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 3 italic_x italic_y start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_RELOP 0. in detail. So, all we need to know here are the following simple rules:[19] [19] [19] In the following, f⁢(x,y)𝑓𝑥𝑦f(x,y)italic_f ( italic_x , italic_y ) represents a Diophantine expression (like x2+3⁢x⁢ysuperscript𝑥23𝑥𝑦x^{2}+3xyitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 3 italic_x italic_y) in two variables noting that this applies to Diophantine expressions in more than two variables (e.g. x2+3⁢x⁢y−5⁢z3superscript𝑥23𝑥𝑦5superscript𝑧3x^{2}+3xy-5z^{3}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 3 italic_x italic_y - 5 italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT).

∙∙\bullet∙ If f⁢(x,y)=0𝑓𝑥𝑦0f(x,y)=0italic_f ( italic_x , italic_y ) = 0 then f⁢(x,y)=m0superscript𝑚𝑓𝑥𝑦0f(x,y)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle m}}{{=}}0italic_f ( italic_x , italic_y ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG end_RELOP 0 for any ℕ∋m>1containsℕ𝑚1\mathbb{N}\ni m>1blackboard_N ∋ italic_m > 1, and hence (by contraposition) if f⁢(x,y)≠m0superscript𝑚𝑓𝑥𝑦0f(x,y)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle m}}{{\neq}}0italic_f ( italic_x , italic_y ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG ≠ end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG end_RELOP 0 for a specific m𝑚mitalic_m then f⁢(x,y)≠0𝑓𝑥𝑦0f(x,y)\neq 0italic_f ( italic_x , italic_y ) ≠ 0.

∙∙\bullet∙ If f⁢(x,y)=m0superscript𝑚𝑓𝑥𝑦0f(x,y)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle m}}{{=}}0italic_f ( italic_x , italic_y ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG end_RELOP 0 for all ℕ∋m>1containsℕ𝑚1\mathbb{N}\ni m>1blackboard_N ∋ italic_m > 1 then f⁢(x,y)=0𝑓𝑥𝑦0f(x,y)=0italic_f ( italic_x , italic_y ) = 0.

7.2 Purposes of Modular Reduction and Analysis

The main (or general) purpose of using modular reduction and analysis as an aiding tool for solving Diophantine equations is to reduce the effort (required for searching for solution) by exploiting the versatile collection of rules (or techniques or ……\ldots…) of modular arithmetic and its rather simplified mathematical machinery (such as the possible use of small numbers or the classification of integers in a rather simple and well organized residue systems). However, there are many specific purposes that come under this general purpose. In the following list, we try to outline some of the common specific purposes (or benefits or objectives etc.) of using modular reduction and analysis in solving Diophantine equations where we mostly rely for explanation and clarification on the examples that we discussed and investigated elsewhere:

  1. 1.

    Showing non-solvability of the Diophantine equation (see for instance the examples of Eqs. 1 and 3).

  2. 2.

    Removing some variables and hence simplifying the analysis of the given equation (see for instance the example of Eq. 2).

  3. 3.

    Revealing patterns and clues that can help in solving the Diophantine equation (see for instance the examples of Eqs. 4 and 5).

We note in this regard that the employed modular reduction may not introduce any “visible” change on the original Diophantine equation apart from converting it from an ordinary equation to a congruence equation.

7.3 Recommendations and Guidelines

We already discussed the main recommendations and guidelines about the use of modular reduction and analysis during our discussion of specific types of Diophantine equations (see for instance §§\S§ 6.2.4 and §§\S§ 6.3.4). So, in the following points we just outline and summarize what we have given earlier:

∙∙\bullet∙ Try to find and use small reduction moduli when possible.

∙∙\bullet∙ Try to find and use a prime numbers (as a moduli) when possible.

∙∙\bullet∙ Consider using more than one reduction modulo in the analysis.

∙∙\bullet∙ Remember that modular reduction and analysis is primarily a tool for showing non-solvability (see the rules of §§\S§ 7.1 as well as §§\S§ 7.4). However, it is commonly used (with further analysis and extra effort) for investigating and finding the solutions of the Diophantine equations (if they exist) by imposing certain restrictions and conditions on the solutions and showing their types and forms (such as being odd or divisible by 5).

7.4 Importance of Modular Analysis in Proving Non-Solvability

It is important to note that modular reduction and analysis is especially important in showing and proving that a given Diophantine equation has no solution (either conditionally or unconditionally). In fact, it is usually the only (or at least the main) possible tool/method for doing this job and achieving this purpose. Therefore, as soon as we have a guess or a hint or an indication (e.g. from initial computational investigation; see §§\S§ 5) that a given equation has no solution, we should recall our modular arithmetic techniques and skills to find a modulo in which the given Diophantine equation has no solution when it is reduced in that modulo. In fact, parity analysis and check (which is one of the most common and basic methods for establishing non-solvability; see for instance 2.1) is no more than modular reduction and analysis in modulo 2 (where its wide spread use and its distinction from modular analysis is because of its simplicity and intuitivity as well as other reasons and factors).

8 Factorization Analysis

Factorization analysis is a very common and useful method for analyzing and solving Diophantine equations and hence it should always be considered as one of the first approaches in tackling Diophantine problems. In its most common and simple form (noting that it has various forms and variants as will be outlined next) factorization analysis is based on our ability to produce a factored expression involving variables (on the LHS) that is equal to a specific number (on the RHS). The number of the possible factors on the two sides may also be considered in some variants of factorization analysis since it can eliminate certain possibilities for the solution. Other factors and considerations (such as divisibility or primality/composity) may also be considered and included in more versatile factorization analysis arguments.

In the following subsections we will briefly investigate the aforementioned variants of factorization analysis.

8.1 Simple Factorization Analysis

As indicated in the preamble of this section, simple factorization analysis is based on producing a factored expression involving variables (on the LHS) that is equal to a specific number (on the RHS) where the factors involving variables (on the LHS) can be matched with numeric factors (on the RHS) to produce systems of simultaneous equations that can be solved to produce the solution(s) of the given problem. In fact, some examples of this type of factorization analysis have already been given (see for instance the examples of point 1 of §§\S§ 6.2.5).

8.2 Factorization Analysis based on the Number of Factors

Factorization analysis may also be based on comparing the number of factors (i.e. not their specific form or value) on the two sides of the equation. For example, the function:

f⁢(x,y)=120⁢x5+274⁢x4⁢y+225⁢x3⁢y2+85⁢x2⁢y3+15⁢x⁢y4+y5𝑓𝑥𝑦120superscript𝑥5274superscript𝑥4𝑦225superscript𝑥3superscript𝑦285superscript𝑥2superscript𝑦315𝑥superscript𝑦4superscript𝑦5f(x,y)=120x^{5}+274x^{4}y+225x^{3}y^{2}+85x^{2}y^{3}+15xy^{4}+y^{5}italic_f ( italic_x , italic_y ) = 120 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 274 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y + 225 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 85 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 15 italic_x italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

can be factorized in the following 5-factor form:

f⁢(x,y)=(x+y)⁢(2⁢x+y)⁢(3⁢x+y)⁢(4⁢x+y)⁢(5⁢x+y)𝑓𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦2𝑥𝑦3𝑥𝑦4𝑥𝑦5𝑥𝑦f(x,y)=(x+y)(2x+y)(3x+y)(4x+y)(5x+y)italic_f ( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( italic_x + italic_y ) ( 2 italic_x + italic_y ) ( 3 italic_x + italic_y ) ( 4 italic_x + italic_y ) ( 5 italic_x + italic_y )

and hence we can conclude (through factorization analysis based on the number of factors on the two sides) that f⁢(x,y)=21𝑓𝑥𝑦21f(x,y)=21italic_f ( italic_x , italic_y ) = 21 has no solution (because 21 can be factorized only in 2 or 3 or 4 distinct integer factors) while f⁢(x,y)=45𝑓𝑥𝑦45f(x,y)=45italic_f ( italic_x , italic_y ) = 45 can have (and actually has) solution (because 45 can be factorized into 5 distinct integer factors). However, it should be noticed that this type of factorization analysis is primarily for proving non-solvability and hence solvability (and obtaining the solutions) requires extra work (noting that having the same number of factors on the two sides of equation is a necessary but not sufficient condition for solvability in this type of factorization analysis).

8.3 Factorization with Divisibility Analysis

In this type of factorization analysis we consider employing divisibility arguments of one side (or of factors of one side) by the other side (or by factors of the other side). In fact, some examples of this type of factorization analysis have already been given (see for instance the examples of points 2 and 3 of §§\S§ 6.2.5).

8.4 Factorization with Primality/Composity Analysis

In this type of factorization analysis we consider employing primality/composity arguments where one side (or factors of one side) is compared to the other side (or to factors of the other side) from this perspective (i.e. being prime or composite). Some simple examples of this type of factorization analysis have been given in §§\S§ 2.2.

9 Comparison to Similar Equations and Problems

An ideal way for solving a given Diophantine equation is to compare it to a similar equation whose solutions are known (or whose solutions are easier to obtain) and hence obtain the solutions of the given equation with no effort (or with minimal effort). In fact, sometimes solving a given Diophantine equation may require no more than copying and pasting the solution of a previously-solved problem with some modifications and adaptations to reflect the specific characteristics of the given Diophantine equation. Therefore, it is recommended when tackling a Diophantine equation to consider this method of solution as one of the first options to recall and consider.

As hinted above, the advantage of the method of comparison is simplicity and ease where the effort required to solve the given Diophantine equation is reduced substantially. However, an obvious limitation of this method is that we need to have a similar equation with known (or easy-to-obtain) solutions which is obviously not available in most cases. However, it is useful to search for such an equation in our collection of previously-solved Diophantine equations, and hence keeping an organized and classified “database” of Diophantine equations (with known solutions) is very useful (especially to those who specialize in the subject of Diophantine equations).[20] [20] [20] In fact, this is one reason for organizing and classifying Diophantine equations in our books (see [2, 3]). Some examples of this method are given in the following:

  1. 1.

    Let us assume that we already investigated the Diophantine equation:

    5⁢x3+4⁢y3−9=05superscript𝑥34superscript𝑦3905x^{3}+4y^{3}-9=05 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 4 italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 9 = 0 (15)

    and obtained its solutions which are (x,y)=(1,1)𝑥𝑦11(x,y)=(1,1)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( 1 , 1 ) and (x,y)=(13,−14)𝑥𝑦1314(x,y)=(13,-14)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( 13 , - 14 ). Now, if we have to solve the Diophantine equation:

    5⁢x3−4⁢y3+9=05superscript𝑥34superscript𝑦3905x^{3}-4y^{3}+9=05 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 9 = 0 (16)

    then all we need to do is to change the sign of the x𝑥xitalic_x value of the solutions of Eq. 15 and hence obtain the solutions (x,y)=(−1,1)𝑥𝑦11(x,y)=(-1,1)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( - 1 , 1 ) and (x,y)=(−13,−14)𝑥𝑦1314(x,y)=(-13,-14)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( - 13 , - 14 ). This is because if we multiply Eq. 16 by −11-1- 1 then we obtain:

    5⁢(−x)3+4⁢y3−9=05superscript𝑥34superscript𝑦3905(-x)^{3}+4y^{3}-9=05 ( - italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 4 italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 9 = 0

    Similarly, if we have to solve the Diophantine equation:

    5⁢x3+4⁢y3+9=05superscript𝑥34superscript𝑦3905x^{3}+4y^{3}+9=05 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 4 italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 9 = 0 (17)

    5⁢(−x)3+4⁢(−y)3−9=05superscript𝑥34superscript𝑦3905(-x)^{3}+4(-y)^{3}-9=05 ( - italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 4 ( - italic_y ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 9 = 0

    which is no more than Eq. 15 with the sign of x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y being reversed.

  2. 2.

    Let us assume that we already investigated the Diophantine equation:

    x3+y3+x2+y2=0superscript𝑥3superscript𝑦3superscript𝑥2superscript𝑦20x^{3}+y^{3}+x^{2}+y^{2}=0italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 (18)

  3. 3.

    We should also refer to the examples of §§\S§ 6.4.3 and §§\S§ 6.6.6 where we used the method of comparison for solving some Diophantine equations of certain types.

We should finally note that comparison to similar equations and problems may require some manipulations and transformations (see the examples in §§\S§ 4). In fact, we may even extend the method of comparison beyond direct comparison of two similar equations with a specific form and hence we may consider comparing equations of certain characteristic features (though they may not look similar in form) that make their method of solution (or the rationale and logic behind their method of solution) similar.

10 Symmetries and Cycling Patterns in the Variables

Symmetry in the variables[21] [21] [21] “Symmetry” in the variables of an algebraic expression means that the variables can be exchanged without affecting the expression. of a Diophantine equation is a useful feature that can be exploited in assuming temporarily that the variables have a certain increasing or decreasing order. This should facilitate the search for a solution where the final and complete solution can be obtained eventually by permuting the solution obtained on the base of ordering assumption. So, when tackling a Diophantine equation with total or partial symmetry in its variables it is recommended to consider such a symmetry by synthesizing a logical or mathematical argument that exploits such a symmetry.

We should also look for any cyclic pattern[22] [22] [22] “Cyclic pattern” in the variables of an algebraic expression means that the variables can be exchanged in a certain cyclic order without affecting the expression although the expression is affected if the variables are exchanged without regard to the cyclic order. So, cyclic pattern is a restricted form of symmetry. in the variables of Diophantine equations where this pattern can be exploited similarly, i.e. by assuming initially that a certain variable is the biggest or the smallest (since cycling would allow us to bring this variable to a certain position in the equation where ordering can be exploited to make an argument that leads to the interim solution and this solution can be generalized later by lifting the condition of ordering).

The following are some examples of how symmetry and cyclic pattern in the variables can be exploited in solving Diophantine equations:

  1. 1.

    The Diophantine equation:

    1x+1y=23(x,y∈ℕ)1𝑥1𝑦23𝑥𝑦ℕ\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}=\frac{2}{3}\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{N})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N )

    is symmetric in x,y𝑥𝑦x,yitalic_x , italic_y and hence we can assume initially that x≤y𝑥𝑦x\leq yitalic_x ≤ italic_y. Accordingly, we can argue (based on this assumption and considering the magnitude of the RHS as well as similar factors) that x𝑥xitalic_x must be either 2 (and hence y=6𝑦6y=6italic_y = 6) or 3 (and hence y=3𝑦3y=3italic_y = 3). So, we obtain the interim solutions (x,y)=(2,6)𝑥𝑦26(x,y)=(2,6)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( 2 , 6 ) and (3,3)33(3,3)( 3 , 3 ). Now, if we lift the condition x≤y𝑥𝑦x\leq yitalic_x ≤ italic_y (thanks to the symmetry) we obtain (by permutation) another solution, i.e. (x,y)=(6,2)𝑥𝑦62(x,y)=(6,2)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( 6 , 2 ). So, the given Diophantine equation has only three solutions.

  2. 2.

    The Diophantine equation:

    1x+1y+1z=2(x,y,z∈ℕ)1𝑥1𝑦1𝑧2𝑥𝑦𝑧ℕ\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}=2\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y,z\in\mathbb{N})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_z end_ARG = 2 ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ blackboard_N )

    is symmetric in x,y,z𝑥𝑦𝑧x,y,zitalic_x , italic_y , italic_z and hence we can assume initially that x≤y≤z𝑥𝑦𝑧x\leq y\leq zitalic_x ≤ italic_y ≤ italic_z. Accordingly, we can argue (based on this assumption) that x𝑥xitalic_x cannot be greater than 1 and y𝑦yitalic_y must be 2 and hence z𝑧zitalic_z must be 2. This argument produces the interim solution (x,y,z)=(1,2,2)𝑥𝑦𝑧122(x,y,z)=(1,2,2)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ( 1 , 2 , 2 ) which can be generalized by permutation (thanks to the symmetry) to produce the other two solutions, i.e. (x,y,z)=(2,1,2)𝑥𝑦𝑧212(x,y,z)=(2,1,2)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ( 2 , 1 , 2 ) and (2,2,1)221(2,2,1)( 2 , 2 , 1 ).

  3. 3.

    The Diophantine equation:

    x+y+z=xyz(x,y,z∈ℤ,xyz≠0)x+y+z=xyz\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y,z\in\mathbb{Z},\ xyz\neq 0)italic_x + italic_y + italic_z = italic_x italic_y italic_z ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y italic_z ≠ 0 )

    is symmetric in x,y,z𝑥𝑦𝑧x,y,zitalic_x , italic_y , italic_z and hence we can assume initially that |x|≤|y|≤|z|𝑥𝑦𝑧|x|\leq|y|\leq|z|| italic_x | ≤ | italic_y | ≤ | italic_z |. This argument produces the two interim solutions (x,y,z)=±(1,2,3)𝑥𝑦𝑧plus-or-minus123(x,y,z)=\pm(1,2,3)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ± ( 1 , 2 , 3 ) which can be generalized by permutation (thanks to the symmetry) to produce the other ten solutions, i.e. (x,y,z)=±(1,3,2)𝑥𝑦𝑧plus-or-minus132(x,y,z)=\pm(1,3,2)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ± ( 1 , 3 , 2 ), ±(2,1,3)plus-or-minus213\pm(2,1,3)± ( 2 , 1 , 3 ), ±(2,3,1)plus-or-minus231\pm(2,3,1)± ( 2 , 3 , 1 ), ±(3,1,2)plus-or-minus312\pm(3,1,2)± ( 3 , 1 , 2 ), ±(3,2,1)plus-or-minus321\pm(3,2,1)± ( 3 , 2 , 1 ).

  4. 4.

    The Diophantine equation:

    x2+y2=z2(x,y,z⁢ are consecutive natural numbers)superscript𝑥2superscript𝑦2superscript𝑧2𝑥𝑦𝑧 are consecutive natural numbersx^{2}+y^{2}=z^{2}\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y,z\textrm{ are consecutive natural % numbers})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z are consecutive natural numbers )

    is symmetric in x,y𝑥𝑦x,yitalic_x , italic_y and hence we can assume initially that x<y𝑥𝑦x<yitalic_x < italic_y (i.e. y=x+1𝑦𝑥1y=x+1italic_y = italic_x + 1), that is:
    x2+(x+1)2=(x+2)2superscript𝑥2superscript𝑥12superscript𝑥22x^{2}+(x+1)^{2}=(x+2)^{2}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( italic_x + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_x + 2 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT →→\rightarrow→ x2−2⁢x−3=0superscript𝑥22𝑥30x^{2}-2x-3=0italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_x - 3 = 0 →→\rightarrow→ (x+1)⁢(x−3)=0𝑥1𝑥30(x+1)(x-3)=0( italic_x + 1 ) ( italic_x - 3 ) = 0
    i.e. x=3𝑥3x=3italic_x = 3 (noting that x∈ℕ𝑥ℕx\in\mathbb{N}italic_x ∈ blackboard_N).     The Diophantine equation:

    x+y+z+w=x⁢y⁢z⁢w(x,y,z,w∈ℕ)𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑤𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑤𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑤ℕx+y+z+w=xyzw\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y,z,w\in\mathbb{N})italic_x + italic_y + italic_z + italic_w = italic_x italic_y italic_z italic_w ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z , italic_w ∈ blackboard_N )

  6. 6.

    The Diophantine equation x4+y4+z4=3042superscript𝑥4superscript𝑦4superscript𝑧43042x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}=3042italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 3042 (which will be discussed in §§\S§ 11) is another example of symmetry in the variables.

  7. 7.

    The Diophantine equation:

    x3⁢y+y3⁢z+z3⁢x=1(x,y,z∈ℕ0)superscript𝑥3𝑦superscript𝑦3𝑧superscript𝑧3𝑥1𝑥𝑦𝑧superscriptℕ0x^{3}y+y^{3}z+z^{3}x=1\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y,z\in\mathbb{N}^{0})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_z + italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x = 1 ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

    is not symmetric in its variables, e.g. if we exchange x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y we get:

    y3⁢x+x3⁢z+z3⁢y=1superscript𝑦3𝑥superscript𝑥3𝑧superscript𝑧3𝑦1y^{3}x+x^{3}z+z^{3}y=1italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x + italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_z + italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y = 1

    which is not the same as the original equation. However, it is cyclic in its variables, i.e. if we exchange x→y→𝑥𝑦x\rightarrow yitalic_x → italic_y, y→z→𝑦𝑧y\rightarrow zitalic_y → italic_z and z→x→𝑧𝑥z\rightarrow xitalic_z → italic_x we get:

    y3⁢z+z3⁢x+x3⁢y=1superscript𝑦3𝑧superscript𝑧3𝑥superscript𝑥3𝑦1y^{3}z+z^{3}x+x^{3}y=1italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_z + italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x + italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y = 1

    which is the same as the original equation (apart from the order of terms which is irrelevant in this context). So, we can assume initially that x≤y𝑥𝑦x\leq yitalic_x ≤ italic_y and x≤z𝑥𝑧x\leq zitalic_x ≤ italic_z (since we can cycle the variables to put x𝑥xitalic_x in such a position in the equation noting that we cannot assume that x≤y≤z𝑥𝑦𝑧x\leq y\leq zitalic_x ≤ italic_y ≤ italic_z because such an ordering flexibility requires full symmetry). Accordingly, we can argue (based on this assumption) that x𝑥xitalic_x must be 0 (because otherwise the LHS will be greater than 1) and hence we must have y=z=1𝑦𝑧1y=z=1italic_y = italic_z = 1. So, the interim solution is (x,y,z)=(0,1,1)𝑥𝑦𝑧011(x,y,z)=(0,1,1)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ( 0 , 1 , 1 ). Now, if we cycle the variables we obtain the other two solutions, i.e. (x,y,z)=(1,0,1)𝑥𝑦𝑧101(x,y,z)=(1,0,1)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ( 1 , 0 , 1 ) and (x,y,z)=(1,1,0)𝑥𝑦𝑧110(x,y,z)=(1,1,0)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ( 1 , 1 , 0 ).

11 Upper and Lower Bounds

Imposing upper or/and lower bounds or limits (usually in the form of bounding inequalities) on the potential solutions should be considered when tackling Diophantine equations (e.g. when dealing with equations involving fractions). This can reduce the complexity of the process of search for solution substantially since it reduces the number of possible solutions. In fact, it can reduce this number from being infinite to finite and this should allow the use of more simple methods of inspection and search (e.g. by computational tools and techniques).

The two main considerations for imposing such bounds are:

∙∙\bullet∙ Magnitude[23] [23] [23] “Magnitude” here should mean the position on the number line rather than the absolute value (as we usually use). considerations where the potential solutions cannot exceed in magnitude certain (upper or/and lower) limits. Bounds imposed by magnitude considerations can impose a limit on the number of possible solutions, i.e. they can make this number finite when both lower and upper bounds are imposed.

∙∙\bullet∙ Sign considerations where the potential solutions can be of only one type of sign (i.e. positive or negative). Although bounds imposed by sign considerations should reduce the difficulty of the problem they usually do not impose a limit on the number of possible solutions, i.e. this number remains infinite. In fact, sign considerations can be seen as a special form of magnitude considerations (which we discussed in the previous point) where only upper/lower bound is imposed.

The following are a few examples for the use of bounds (and bounding arguments) in solving Diophantine problems:

  1. 1.

    Consider the following Diophantine equation:

    1x+1y=z(x,y,z∈ℤ,xy≠0)\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}=z\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y,z\in\mathbb{Z},\ xy\neq 0)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_x end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG = italic_z ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_x italic_y ≠ 0 )

    It should be obvious that the LHS (and hence z𝑧zitalic_z) cannot be less than −22-2- 2 or greater than +22+2+ 2 and hence:
    ∙∙\bullet∙ If z=−2𝑧2z=-2italic_z = - 2 then (x,y,z)=(−1,−1,−2)𝑥𝑦𝑧112(x,y,z)=(-1,-1,-2)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ( - 1 , - 1 , - 2 ).
    ∙∙\bullet∙ If z=−1𝑧1z=-1italic_z = - 1 then (x,y,z)=(−2,−2,−1)𝑥𝑦𝑧221(x,y,z)=(-2,-2,-1)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ( - 2 , - 2 , - 1 ).
    ∙∙\bullet∙ If z=0𝑧0z=0italic_z = 0 then (x,y,z)=(k,−k,0)𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑘𝑘0(x,y,z)=(k,-k,0)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ( italic_k , - italic_k , 0 ) where ℤ∋k≠0containsℤ𝑘0\mathbb{Z}\ni k\neq 0blackboard_Z ∋ italic_k ≠ 0.
    ∙∙\bullet∙ If z=1𝑧1z=1italic_z = 1 then (x,y,z)=(2,2,1)𝑥𝑦𝑧221(x,y,z)=(2,2,1)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) = ( 2 , 2 , 1 ).

12 Reduction of Domain

When dealing with Diophantine equations it is recommended to consider reducing the domain of solution temporarily until a solution is found (for the reduced domain) where this solution can be extended and generalized later on to reach the final and complete solution for the entire domain. For example, if we are dealing with a Diophantine equation in the domain of integers ℤℤ\mathbb{Z}blackboard_Z involving variables with even powers then we can start by considering its solution in the domain of natural numbers ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N (instead of ℤℤ\mathbb{Z}blackboard_Z) where the final and complete solution can be obtained later on by extending the domain to the negative integers (noting that even powers do not distinguish between positive and negative bases).

The reduction of domain may also take the form of splitting the domain into parts and dealing with these parts separately (and usually independently). For example, we may consider splitting[24] [24] [24] Such a split can involve some or all variables (depending on the nature of the Diophantine problem and the tackling strategy). the integer domain of a Diophantine equation to negative integers and positive integers where we investigate these sub-domains separately (e.g. by applying different arguments and techniques to each sub-domain) and the final solution (over the entire integer domain) will be obtained in the end by taking the union of the solutions in the sub-domains (noting the possibility of having no solution in some or all sub-domains). Such a scenario may also be considered by splitting the domain to odd integers and even integers (or to integers greater than and integers less than a certain value or ……\ldots…) where we deal with these sub-domains separately and obtain the entire solution in stages (as before).

Anyway, reduction/splitting of domain in its various shapes and forms is a very common approach in tackling and solving Diophantine problems and hence it should always be considered since it usually brings many benefits (such as reducing the complexity of the given problem and making the strategy of tackling it tidy and organized) and can provide key clues for solving it. It can also provide a partial solution to the given problem, i.e. when the investigation leads to solution only in some parts of the domain (where this partial solution can be extended in the future to include the entire domain or where the original problem is modified to consider such a restriction on the domain).

We present in the following some examples for the reduction of domain in tackling Diophantine problems:

  1. 1.

    The “Pythagorean equation” x2⁢a+y2⁢b=z2⁢csuperscript𝑥2𝑎superscript𝑦2𝑏superscript𝑧2𝑐x^{2a}+y^{2b}=z^{2c}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (where x,y,z∈ℤ𝑥𝑦𝑧ℤx,y,z\in\mathbb{Z}italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ blackboard_Z and a,b,c∈ℕ𝑎𝑏𝑐ℕa,b,c\in\mathbb{N}italic_a , italic_b , italic_c ∈ blackboard_N) is an obvious example for the possibility of considering the reduction of domain where we can start by considering initially the solutions in the reduced domain of natural numbers (or non-negative numbers). Any solution obtained in this restricted domain can then be extended to the domain of integers by considering all the possible sign alterations in the values of the variables in the natural solutions or non-negative solutions).

  2. 2.

    Another obvious example for the reduction of domain is the Diophantine equations of the Pell type (see §§\S§ 6.2.3) where we can obtain the solutions in the reduced domain of natural numbers first (e.g. by the use of standard Pell’s techniques) and extend these solutions subsequently to the domain of integers by considering all the possible sign alterations in the values of the variables in the natural solutions.

  3. 3.

    Consider the following Diophantine equation:

    x3⁢y+3⁢x⁢y3+7⁢x⁢y=1085(x,y∈ℤ)superscript𝑥3𝑦3𝑥superscript𝑦37𝑥𝑦1085𝑥𝑦ℤx^{3}y+3xy^{3}+7xy=1085\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y + 3 italic_x italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 7 italic_x italic_y = 1085 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z )

    It is fairly obvious that x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y have the same sign (because otherwise the LHS will be non-positive). Now, if we start by assuming that x,y∈ℕ𝑥𝑦ℕx,y\in\mathbb{N}italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N then we can easily obtain the solution (x,y)=(1,7)𝑥𝑦17(x,y)=(1,7)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( 1 , 7 ). Following this, we extend this reduced domain (by lifting the condition x,y∈ℕ𝑥𝑦ℕx,y\in\mathbb{N}italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N) to obtain the other solution, i.e. (x,y)=(−1,−7)𝑥𝑦17(x,y)=(-1,-7)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( - 1 , - 7 ) noting that the equation does not change by reversing the sign of x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y.

  4. 4.

    Consider the following Diophantine equation:

    xy+xy=2(x,y∈ℤ,y≠0)\frac{x}{y}+xy=2\hskip 56.9055pt(x,y\in\mathbb{Z},\ y\neq 0)divide start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_ARG italic_y end_ARG + italic_x italic_y = 2 ( italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_Z , italic_y ≠ 0 )

    It is obvious that x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y have the same sign (because otherwise the LHS will be non-positive). Now, if we start by assuming that x,y∈ℕ𝑥𝑦ℕx,y\in\mathbb{N}italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N then we can easily obtain the solution (x,y)=(1,1)𝑥𝑦11(x,y)=(1,1)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( 1 , 1 ). Following this, we extend this reduced domain (by lifting the condition x,y∈ℕ𝑥𝑦ℕx,y\in\mathbb{N}italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_N) to obtain the other solution, i.e. (x,y)=(−1,−1)𝑥𝑦11(x,y)=(-1,-1)( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( - 1 , - 1 ) noting that the equation does not change by reversing the sign of x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y.
